tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare provider knowledgeable in transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly turned out, and keep your chest lifted.
Initiate the squat by bending at the hips and knees simultaneously, lowering your hips back and down as if sitting into a chair.
Keep your knees tracking over your toes without collapsing inward, and maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
A good rep feels like controlled mobility through the hips and ankles, with tension in the thighs and glutes but no sharp joint pain.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling as you stand up and inhaling as you lower down.
Stop or regress the movement if you experience sharp pain or discomfort beyond typical muscle fatigue.
If mobility or pain issues persist, seek advice from a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health and exercise.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; start with lower volume and gradually increase as tolerated.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels, so prioritize mobility exercises like bodyweight squats to support joint function and bone strength.
gender_affirming_modifications: Perform the exercise in a private or comfortable space, or with a trusted partner to reduce dysphoria.
Wear clothing that affirms your gender identity and feels comfortable, such as loose pants or shorts that allow full hip and knee movement.
Modify depth or use a chair for support if full squatting feels uncomfortable or dysphoric.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Set up facing a sturdy step or box at a height that allows your hips to sit back gently without fully resting on it.
Keep feet shoulder-width apart, knees tracking over toes, and maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Lower your hips by bending at the hips and knees simultaneously, feeling a stretch in the hips and thighs, then press through the heels to stand.
Avoid letting knees collapse inward or rounding the lower back; a good rep feels controlled with stable balance and smooth movement.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling as you stand up and inhaling as you lower down.
Distinguish between normal muscle stretch and sharp pain; stop or regress if pain occurs in joints or soft tissues.
Regress by reducing depth or using support for balance if needed, and seek medical advice if persistent pain or unusual symptoms arise.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; start with lower volume and intensity to monitor comfort during box squats.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels, so prioritize proper form and gradual progression to support joint integrity.
Allow extra recovery time if experiencing unusual joint stiffness or soreness, and adjust training frequency accordingly.
gender_affirming_modifications: Choose clothing that feels comfortable and affirming, such as loose pants or shorts that do not restrict hip or thigh movement.
Train in a private or trusted environment to reduce dysphoria and increase focus on movement quality.
Modify depth or use a higher step if full range of motion feels uncomfortable or dysphoric, allowing gradual mobility improvement.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Position your back flat against the wall with feet about hip-width apart and a comfortable distance forward to allow knees to bend at roughly 90 degrees.
Keep knees aligned over ankles without letting them extend past toes to protect joint integrity during the hold.
Engage your core and maintain a neutral spine; avoid arching your lower back or leaning forward.
A good rep feels like a steady tension in the thighs and glutes without sharp pain or knee discomfort.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the hold, avoiding breath-holding to maintain oxygen flow and reduce tension.
Distinguish between muscle fatigue and joint pain; stop or regress if you experience sharp or persistent discomfort.
Regress by reducing hold time or knee bend depth if needed, and seek medical advice if pain persists beyond typical muscle soreness.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; start with shorter holds and gradually increase duration to monitor tolerance.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels, so ensure gradual progression and avoid overloading joints to reduce injury risk.
gender_affirming_modifications: Perform the exercise in a private or comfortable space, or with a trusted partner to support safety and reduce dysphoria.
Wear clothing that feels affirming and allows unrestricted movement, such as loose pants and supportive tops.
If the standard wall sit feels uncomfortable, try a modified sit with a higher knee angle or seated chair hold to reduce dysphoria and joint strain.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting new exercise routines to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart.
Engage your core and squeeze your glutes to lift your hips until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees.
Avoid overarching your lower back; focus on lifting through the hips and feeling activation in the glutes and hamstrings.
Lower hips slowly with control, maintaining tension in the glutes throughout the movement.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling as you lift hips and inhaling as you lower.
Stop if you experience sharp pain or unusual discomfort; mild muscle fatigue is normal but pain is not.
Regress by reducing range of motion or performing pelvic tilts if full bridges feel too challenging.
Seek medical advice if persistent pain or unusual symptoms occur during or after exercise.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; start with lower volume and gradually increase as tolerated.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels, so prioritize controlled, pain-free movement to support joint integrity.
Allow extra recovery time if experiencing increased soreness or joint discomfort during early training phases.
gender_affirming_modifications: Perform the exercise in a private or comfortable space to reduce dysphoria and increase focus.
Wear clothing that feels affirming and supportive, such as high-waisted leggings or shorts that cover the hips and pelvis.
If lying on the back feels uncomfortable, try placing a small cushion under the head or neck for added comfort.

tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Lie on your back with one foot flat on the floor and the other leg extended straight.
Engage your glutes and core as you lift your hips off the ground, driving through the heel of the planted foot.
Keep your hips level and avoid arching your lower back; a good rep feels like controlled activation of the glute on the working side.
Lower your hips slowly back down without losing tension in the glutes.
general_safety: Maintain steady breathing throughout the movement, exhaling as you lift your hips and inhaling as you lower.
Stop if you experience sharp pain or discomfort beyond typical muscle fatigue; regress by reducing range of motion or switching to a two-legged bridge.
Consult a healthcare provider if you notice persistent joint pain or unusual symptoms during or after exercise.
hrt_considerations: Be mindful of potential joint or tendon sensitivity changes during hormone therapy; start with lower volume and gradually increase.
Focus on controlled, slow movements to support tendon and bone health, especially if on long-term hormone treatment.

Wear clothing that affirms your gender identity and provides comfort during floor exercises, such as high-waisted leggings or shorts.

tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Start lying on your side with hips and knees bent at about 45 degrees, keeping feet together.
Lift the top knee upward by externally rotating the hip while keeping the pelvis stable and the feet touching.
A good rep feels like controlled activation in the outer hip and glute muscles without twisting the pelvis or lower back.
Avoid letting the hips roll backward or forward and keep movements slow and deliberate.
general_safety: Maintain steady breathing throughout, avoiding breath-holding to support relaxation and control.
Stop or regress the exercise if sharp pain occurs; mild muscle activation discomfort is normal.
Consult a healthcare provider if persistent joint pain or unusual symptoms develop during training.

Bone health can be impacted by hormone levels, so focus on consistent mobility work to support joint function.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Start standing tall, step one leg backward lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about 90 degrees.
Keep your front knee aligned over your ankle and avoid letting it push past your toes to protect the joint.
Engage your quadriceps and glutes to control the movement and maintain balance throughout the lunge.
Feel a gentle stretch in the hip flexors of the rear leg and avoid any sharp pain in knees or hips.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling as you lower and inhaling as you return to standing.
Distinguish between normal muscle stretch and sharp joint pain; stop or regress if pain occurs.
Regress by reducing range of motion or using support if balance or strength is limited, and seek medical advice if persistent pain arises.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; progress slowly to allow tissues to adapt safely.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels, so prioritize controlled, low-impact movements like this to support mobility.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting new exercises to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Start in a split stance with one foot forward and one foot back, keeping hips square and torso upright.
Lower your back knee toward the ground by bending both knees, focusing on controlled hip and knee flexion.
Feel a gentle stretch and activation in the front hip flexors and stabilizing muscles without forcing depth.
Avoid leaning forward excessively or letting the front knee track past the toes to protect joints.
general_safety: Maintain steady breathing throughout the movement, exhaling as you lower and inhaling as you rise.
Stop if you experience sharp pain or joint instability; mild discomfort from stretching is normal but should not be intense.
Regress by reducing range of motion or performing static hip flexor stretches if mobility is limited.
Seek medical advice if persistent pain or unusual joint symptoms occur during or after exercise.
hrt_considerations: Be mindful of potential joint or tendon sensitivity changes during hormone therapy; progress range and load gradually.
Incorporate mobility-focused exercises like split squats to support hip joint health and maintain functional movement.
Allow extra recovery time if experiencing increased soreness or stiffness, especially early in hormone treatment.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Start facing the step with feet hip-width apart and place one foot fully on the step, ensuring the entire foot is stable.
Drive through the heel of the foot on the step to lift your body upward, extending the hip and knee joints while keeping the torso upright.
Avoid pushing off with the trailing leg or letting the knee of the stepping leg collapse inward; maintain alignment over the foot.
Lower back down slowly with control, feeling a gentle stretch in the hip and thigh muscles without locking the knee.
general_safety: Maintain steady breathing throughout the movement, exhaling as you step up and inhaling as you lower down.
Stop or regress the exercise if you experience sharp pain or joint instability; mild muscle fatigue or stretch is normal.
Use a stable, non-slip step surface and consider support (e.g., wall or rail) if balance is a concern.
Seek medical advice if persistent pain or unusual symptoms occur during or after exercise.
hrt_considerations: Be mindful of potential joint or tendon sensitivity during early hormone therapy; start with lower step heights and volume to reduce strain.
Incorporate gradual progression to support bone health, especially if on hormone regimens affecting bone density.
Allow extra recovery time if experiencing increased muscle or joint soreness, adjusting intensity accordingly.
gender_affirming_modifications: Choose a private or comfortable training environment to reduce dysphoria and increase focus during the exercise.
Wear clothing that feels affirming and allows full range of motion without restriction around the hips and legs.
Modify step height or use a lower platform to reduce discomfort or anxiety related to balance and body positioning.

tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Start with feet hip-width apart and slowly lift your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet, focusing on controlled ankle plantarflexion.
Keep your knees straight but not locked, and maintain an upright posture with your core engaged to avoid leaning forward or backward.
Feel a gentle stretch and contraction in your calf muscles; avoid bouncing or using momentum to lift.
Lower your heels slowly back to the floor to complete a smooth, controlled repetition.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling as you lift your heels and inhaling as you lower them.
Stop or regress the exercise if you experience sharp pain or joint instability; mild muscle fatigue or stretch is normal.

hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect tendon and joint sensitivity; prioritize slow, controlled movements to reduce strain on the Achilles tendon.
Bone health can be supported by weight-bearing mobility exercises like calf raises, so include them regularly but avoid overtraining.

gender_affirming_modifications: Perform calf raises in a private or comfortable space to reduce dysphoria and increase focus on movement quality.
Wear clothing that feels affirming and allows full ankle and foot movement without restriction.
If standing is uncomfortable, try seated calf raises as a variation to maintain mobility while reducing dysphoria or fatigue.

tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare or fitness professional knowledgeable in transgender health before starting new exercises to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Start standing tall with one foot flat on the ground and the other leg lifted or bent for balance support.
Slowly raise your heel on the standing leg by pushing through the ball of your foot, feeling a controlled contraction in the calf muscle.
Keep the ankle, knee, and hip aligned and avoid locking the knee; lower the heel back down with control to complete one rep.
A good rep feels like a smooth rise and fall with no wobbling or sharp joint pain.
general_safety: Maintain steady breathing throughout the movement; avoid holding your breath to support blood flow and muscle function.
Stop or regress the exercise if you experience sharp pain or joint instability; mild muscle fatigue or stretch is normal.

tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Start with a resistance band looped around your legs just above the knees or at the ankles for more challenge.
Keep a slight bend in the knees and hips, maintaining a neutral spine and engaged core throughout the lateral steps.
Step sideways slowly and deliberately, feeling tension in the hip abductors and glutes without letting your knees cave inward.
Avoid leaning forward or letting your feet cross; a good rep feels controlled with steady muscle engagement around the hips.
general_safety: Maintain steady breathing throughout the exercise, avoiding breath-holding to support core stability and oxygen flow.
Stop or regress the exercise if you experience sharp pain or joint discomfort beyond typical muscle fatigue.

Increased red blood cell levels from testosterone may impact recovery; ensure adequate rest between sessions.
Focus on mobility and controlled movement to support joint health and reduce injury risk during training.
gender_affirming_modifications: Choose clothing that feels comfortable and affirms your gender identity, such as looser pants or compression shorts.
Train in a private or trusted environment if it helps reduce dysphoria or anxiety during movement practice.
Modify the range of motion or resistance to suit your comfort level, prioritizing movements that feel safe and affirming.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Start in a forearm or full plank position with elbows under shoulders and body in a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core by drawing the belly button toward the spine and avoid sagging hips or raised buttocks to maintain neutral alignment.
Keep the neck neutral by looking down or slightly ahead to prevent strain; a good rep feels like steady tension in the abdominal muscles without pain.
Avoid locking elbows or letting shoulders collapse; maintain active shoulder stability throughout the hold.
general_safety: Maintain steady breathing throughout the hold; avoid breath-holding to support core engagement and oxygen flow.
Distinguish between muscle fatigue and sharp pain; stop or regress the exercise if pain occurs.
Regress by reducing hold time or switching to easier variations if form breaks down or discomfort increases.
Seek medical advice if experiencing persistent joint pain, unusual swelling, or other concerning symptoms during or after exercise.
hrt_considerations: Allow extra recovery time if experiencing joint or tendon sensitivity, as hormone therapy can influence tissue response to load.
Focus on gradual progression to support bone health and avoid overloading connective tissues, especially early in hormone therapy.
Monitor for any unusual discomfort around joints and adjust intensity accordingly to accommodate changes in muscle and tendon properties.
binding_considerations: Be mindful that binding can restrict breathing and increase heat; take breaks as needed and avoid holding the plank for extended periods initially.
Consider loosening or removing the binder during exercise if breathing feels compromised or if discomfort arises in the chest or shoulders.
Start with shorter holds and gradually increase duration to manage binder-related pressure and avoid excessive strain.
gender_affirming_modifications: Train in a private or comfortable space or with a trusted partner to reduce dysphoria and increase safety.
Wear clothing that feels affirming and allows full range of motion without restriction, such as compression tops or loose shirts.
Modify the plank by performing it on knees or against a wall to reduce upper body load and accommodate comfort levels.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting new exercises to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Start on your knees with forearms on the ground, elbows under shoulders, and keep your spine neutral from head to hips.
Engage your core by drawing your belly button gently toward your spine without holding your breath.
Avoid sagging hips or raising your buttocks too high; a good rep feels like steady tension in your abdominal muscles without strain in your lower back.
Keep your neck aligned with your spine by looking down or slightly forward to prevent tension.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the exercise; avoid holding your breath to maintain core engagement and oxygen flow.
Stop if you experience sharp pain or numbness; mild muscle fatigue or discomfort is normal but pain is a signal to regress.

tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare provider knowledgeable in transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Start lying on your back with arms extended toward the ceiling and knees bent at 90 degrees over hips.
Slowly lower the opposite arm and leg toward the floor while keeping your lower back gently pressed into the ground.
Focus on controlled, smooth movements to engage the core without arching the lower back or straining the neck.
Avoid rushing reps; a good repetition feels like steady core engagement and stability through the torso.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling during the lowering phase to maintain core engagement.
Stop or regress the exercise if you experience sharp pain or unusual discomfort in the back or hips.

hrt_considerations: Testosterone therapy may affect recovery times; allow adequate rest between sets to avoid overfatigue.
Be mindful of joint or tendon sensitivity, especially if starting or adjusting hormone therapy; progress gradually.
Maintain bone health with consistent weight-bearing and core exercises like the Dead Bug to support structural integrity.

form_focus: Start on all fours with wrists under shoulders and knees under hips, maintaining a neutral spine throughout.

Avoid locking the elbow or knee; maintain a soft bend to protect joints and promote muscle engagement.

form_focus: Start in a side-lying position with your elbow directly under your shoulder to support your upper body.

form_focus: Start lying on your back with hands lightly supporting your head, elbows wide to avoid neck strain.

Seek medical advice if experiencing persistent pain, unusual swelling, or discomfort that limits daily activities.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; start with lower volume and gradually increase to allow adaptation.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels, so prioritize proper form to reduce injury risk during push-ups.
Allow extra recovery time if experiencing joint discomfort, and consider incorporating mobility work to support shoulder health.
binding_considerations: Be mindful that binding can restrict breathing and increase heat; take breaks as needed to avoid breathlessness.
Reduce set length or intensity if binding causes discomfort in the chest or limits range of motion.
Consider loosening or removing the binder during exercise sessions to improve comfort and performance.
post_op_considerations: After chest surgery, avoid push-ups until cleared by a healthcare provider to protect healing tissues and scars.
When resuming, start with wall or incline push-ups to reduce load on the chest and monitor for any pain or tightness.
Scar tissue may affect sensation and mobility; gentle stretching and gradual strengthening can support recovery.
gender_affirming_modifications: Train in a private or comfortable space, or with a trusted partner, to reduce dysphoria during upper body exercises.
Wear clothing that affirms your gender identity and feels comfortable, such as compression shirts or loose tops.
Modify push-ups by performing them on knees or against a wall to reduce intensity and increase control.

tips.disclaimer: Always consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Start in a modified plank position with knees on the ground, hands shoulder-width apart, and wrists aligned under shoulders.
Lower your chest toward the floor by bending elbows while keeping a straight line from head to knees, engaging core and avoiding sagging hips.
Press back up by extending elbows fully without locking them, feeling controlled movement through shoulders and chest.
Avoid letting hips drop or pike up; a good rep feels smooth and controlled with tension in the upper body and core.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling on the push phase and inhaling on the lowering phase.
Stop if you experience sharp pain or numbness; mild discomfort is normal but pain signals should be respected.
Regress by reducing range of motion or taking longer rest breaks if fatigue or form breakdown occurs.
Seek medical advice if persistent pain or unusual symptoms develop during or after exercise.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; prioritize slow, controlled reps to reduce strain on shoulders and wrists.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels; maintain consistent mobility work to support joint function and reduce injury risk.
Allow extra recovery time if experiencing increased joint discomfort, and adjust volume accordingly.
binding_considerations: If wearing a binder, ensure it is not too tight to restrict breathing during the exercise.
Limit set duration and volume to prevent overheating and discomfort in the chest and upper body.
Consider removing the binder for mobility-focused sessions if safe and comfortable to do so.
post_op_considerations: After chest or top surgery, start with very gentle range of motion and avoid pushing into pain around scars or sensitive areas.
Modify hand placement or range of motion to reduce pressure on healing tissue and hypertrophic scars.
Consult your surgical team before resuming upper body loading exercises to ensure safe progression.
gender_affirming_modifications: Perform the exercise in a private or comfortable space, or with a trusted partner to reduce dysphoria.
Wear clothing that affirms your gender identity and feels comfortable, such as loose tops or compression garments that do not bind tightly.
Try alternative positions like wall push-ups or incline push-ups if floor positioning feels dysphoric or uncomfortable.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine.
form_focus: Stand facing a wall with feet hip-width apart and about an arms length away.
Place hands flat on the wall at shoulder height and width, keeping elbows slightly bent.
Engage your core and slowly bend elbows to bring your chest toward the wall, feeling a gentle stretch in the shoulders and chest.
Push back to the starting position without locking elbows; a good rep feels controlled and smooth without pain.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling as you push away from the wall.
Stop if you feel sharp pain or significant discomfort; mild muscle stretch or fatigue is normal.
Regress by reducing range of motion or number of repetitions if needed, and seek medical advice if pain persists.
hrt_considerations: Testosterone therapy may increase joint and tendon sensitivity; start with low reps and progress gradually to avoid overuse.
Bone health can be supported by consistent, low-impact mobility exercises like wall push-ups to maintain upper body function.
Allow extra recovery time if experiencing joint stiffness or discomfort, especially early in hormone therapy.
binding_considerations: Binder wear can increase chest and shoulder heat; keep sets short and take breaks to avoid overheating.
Focus on controlled breathing to prevent breath restriction; pause or remove the binder if breathing feels compromised.
Reduce intensity or volume if chest or shoulder discomfort arises due to binding.
gender_affirming_modifications: Perform this exercise in a private or comfortable space, or with a trusted partner to enhance safety and confidence.
Wear clothing that feels affirming and allows full range of motion without discomfort, such as loose tops or sports bras.
Modify hand placement or stance width to reduce dysphoria related to chest or shoulder positioning.

tips.disclaimer: Consult a healthcare provider familiar with transgender health before starting or modifying your exercise routine to ensure safety and appropriateness.
form_focus: Set up facing a bench with hands placed shoulder-width apart on the edge, keeping wrists aligned under shoulders.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels by engaging the core and glutes; lower your chest toward the bench by bending elbows while keeping them at about a 45-degree angle from the body.
A good rep feels controlled with tension in the chest, shoulders, and triceps without pain; avoid sagging hips or flaring elbows excessively.
general_safety: Breathe steadily throughout the movement, exhaling on the push phase and inhaling on the lowering phase.
Distinguish between muscle fatigue and sharp pain; stop or regress the exercise if pain occurs.
Regress by increasing the incline height or performing wall push-ups if needed, and seek medical advice if persistent discomfort or unusual symptoms arise.
hrt_considerations: Hormone therapy may affect joint and tendon sensitivity; start with lower volume and intensity to monitor comfort during movement.
Bone health can be influenced by hormone levels, so prioritize gradual progression and proper form to reduce injury risk.
binding_considerations: If wearing a binder, be mindful of restricted breathing and heat buildup; take breaks as needed and consider shorter sets.
Avoid high volume or maximal effort sets while bound to prevent discomfort or respiratory strain.
post_op_considerations: After chest or top surgery, allow adequate healing time before performing incline push-ups to avoid stress on incisions or scars.
Modify hand placement or range of motion to reduce pressure on sensitive scar tissue or areas with altered sensation.
gender_affirming_modifications: Train in a private or comfortable space or with a trusted partner to reduce dysphoria during upper body exercises.
Wear clothing that affirms your gender identity and feels comfortable, such as compression shirts or loose tops, depending on preference.
Consider wall push-ups or reduced incline angles as alternative variations if the standard incline push-up feels dysphoric or physically challenging.
